question.text: What share of global energy will come from renewable sources in 2050?

config.context: Current renewable share: ~15% (2024). Paris targets: 60-70% by 2050. Key uncertainties: policy ambition, battery/storage costs, grid infrastructure, fossil fuel phase-out pace, nuclear expansion.

uncertainties.name: Green Technology Costs
uncertainties.description: The speed of renewable energy cost declines and efficiency gains will determine whether the energy transition creates massive productivity improvements and new industries (boosting GDP growth) or remains an expensive burden that drags on economic performance through higher energy costs and stranded fossil fuel investments.
uncertainties.low_state: Renewable costs plateau at current levels with limited efficiency gains, making the transition expensive and economically disruptive
uncertainties.high_state: Renewable costs fall dramatically with breakthrough efficiency gains, creating massive productivity improvements and new industries
signals: By December 2028, global weighted average cost of solar PV falls below $0.02/kWh, per IRENA Global Energy Transformation report
By June 2029, at least 5 countries achieve grid-scale battery storage costs below $50/kWh, per BloombergNEF Energy Storage Market Outlook
By December 2027, green hydrogen production costs fall below $2/kg in at least 3 major economies, per IEA Global Hydrogen Review
By December 2030, renewable energy accounts for >60% of global electricity generation, per IEA World Energy Outlook data
By June 2028, total global clean energy investment exceeds $3 trillion annually, per IEA World Energy Investment report

uncertainties.name: Climate Policy Coordination
uncertainties.description: Whether major economies implement strong, coordinated climate policies will determine if the energy transition creates orderly investment flows and new global markets (supporting GDP growth) or results in fragmented policies, trade disputes, and economic disruption from policy uncertainty and stranded assets.
uncertainties.low_state: Fragmented, weak climate policies create investment uncertainty, trade conflicts, and economic disruption
uncertainties.high_state: Strong, coordinated global climate policies create clear investment signals and new international markets
signals: By December 2027, US, EU, China, and India all implement carbon pricing mechanisms covering >80% of their emissions, per World Bank Carbon Pricing Dashboard
By June 2028, G20 countries collectively commit to >$500 billion annual climate finance flows to developing nations, per OECD climate finance tracking
By December 2029, global fossil fuel subsidies fall below $200 billion annually, per IMF and OECD subsidy databases
By December 2026, at least 50 countries implement border carbon adjustments on major industrial imports, per WTO trade monitoring reports
By June 2030, global green bond issuance exceeds $2 trillion annually, per Climate Bonds Initiative market data

scenarios.name: Green Breakthrough Boom
scenarios.description: Dramatic renewable cost reductions combined with coordinated global climate policies create a virtuous cycle of investment and innovation. Energy becomes cheaper while economic productivity soars from new clean industries.

uncertainty_states.Green Technology Costs: Renewable costs fall dramatically with breakthrough efficiency gains, creating massive productivity improvements and new industries
uncertainty_states.Climate Policy Coordination: Strong, coordinated global climate policies create clear investment signals and new international markets

key_drivers: Breakthrough solar/battery cost reductions below grid parity
Coordinated carbon pricing creates massive clean investment flows
International climate finance accelerates developing nation transitions
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario requires both technological breakthroughs AND policy coordination - without both, investment flows and adoption rates cannot reach the levels needed for 80%+ renewable share
signals: By December 2028, global weighted average cost of solar PV falls below $0.02/kWh, per IRENA Global Energy Transformation report

scenarios.name: Coordinated Transition
scenarios.description: Strong global climate policies drive steady renewable adoption despite modest technology cost improvements. International cooperation overcomes higher transition costs through coordinated investment and financing.

uncertainty_states.Green Technology Costs: Renewable costs plateau at current levels with limited efficiency gains, making the transition expensive and economically disruptive
uncertainty_states.Climate Policy Coordination: Strong, coordinated global climate policies create clear investment signals and new international markets

key_drivers: Carbon pricing and fossil fuel subsidy removal create renewable competitiveness
Massive international climate finance flows enable global transition
Border carbon adjustments prevent carbon leakage
Policy certainty drives investment despite higher costs
scenarios.why_exclusive: This represents the policy-driven transition path where coordination compensates for limited technology breakthroughs - incompatible with scenarios assuming major cost reductions or policy fragmentation

scenarios.name: Tech-Driven Disruption
scenarios.description: Breakthrough renewable cost reductions drive rapid adoption despite fragmented climate policies. Market forces and economic competitiveness overcome policy uncertainty as clean energy becomes definitively cheaper.

uncertainty_states.Green Technology Costs: Renewable costs fall dramatically with breakthrough efficiency gains, creating massive productivity improvements and new industries
uncertainty_states.Climate Policy Coordination: Fragmented, weak climate policies create investment uncertainty, trade conflicts, and economic disruption

key_drivers: Ultra-low renewable costs make fossil fuels economically unviable
Private sector investment flows despite policy fragmentation
Regional leaders drive adoption while others lag
scenarios.why_exclusive: This scenario assumes technology breakthroughs can overcome policy fragmentation - cannot coexist with scenarios requiring coordinated policies or assuming limited technology progress

scenarios.name: Fragmented Struggle
scenarios.description: Limited technology progress combined with weak climate policies creates a slow, uneven renewable transition. High costs and policy uncertainty lead to regional disparities and economic disruption in the energy sector.

uncertainty_states.Green Technology Costs: Renewable costs plateau at current levels with limited efficiency gains, making the transition expensive and economically disruptive
uncertainty_states.Climate Policy Coordination: Fragmented, weak climate policies create investment uncertainty, trade conflicts, and economic disruption

key_drivers: High renewable costs limit adoption to wealthy regions
Policy uncertainty reduces long-term investment commitments
Continued fossil fuel subsidies distort energy markets
Trade conflicts over green technology and resources
scenarios.why_exclusive: This represents the combination of worst-case outcomes for both uncertainties - cannot coexist with scenarios assuming either technological breakthroughs or policy coordination

indicator_bundle.Regional renewable disparity: >40 percentage points between leaders and laggards

mece_reasoning: These scenarios are MECE because they map the 2x2 matrix of uncertainty states to distinct renewable energy outcome ranges that cannot overlap. The 'Green Breakthrough Boom' (80-85%) requires both technological breakthroughs AND policy coordination. 'Coordinated Transition' (65-75%) shows policy can drive transition despite limited tech progress. 'Tech-Driven Disruption' (60-70%) demonstrates how breakthrough costs can overcome policy fragmentation. 'Fragmented Struggle' (35-50%) represents the combination of limited progress on both dimensions. The GDP ranges are mutually exclusive and collectively cover the plausible space from minimal progress to maximum feasible renewable adoption by 2050.
